title: Storm chances, high heat, then turning a page in the Miami Valley
description: If you’re not a fan of the heat, another cold front should bring us a cooling trend through the following work week.
content:
A weak cold front is impacting the Miami Valley over the next 24 hours, according to Storm Center 7’s Meteorologist Ryan Marando.

That means Wednesday will be the best chance of rain we will see this week.

After 1 pm Wednesday, scattered coverage of storms will be over the Miami Valley until the late evening hours, Marando said.

Some areas may stay dry, but any of the downpours will come with heavy rain, lightning strikes, and even some gusty winds. The good news is we are not expecting severe weather, but not a bad idea to have an umbrella.

Many Montgomery County and a few Preble County schools are heading back to the classroom tomorrow.

The bus stop forecast is dry and muggy in the morning with low temperatures in the 70s, but those storms could impact some heading home from school, according to Marando.

Thursday could have an isolated shower in the afternoon, but this is the one cooler day before the high heat returns.

Friday and both days this weekend will have feels-like temperatures surging into the 90s, even approaching 100.

If you’re not a fan of the heat, another cold front should bring us a cooling trend through the following work week, according to Marando.

And if our average has anything to say about it, things will start to cool off.

Officially in Dayton, our average high on August 12 is 85 degrees; however, by next Thursday, August 21, our average high drops to 84 degrees and will continue to cool through till winter.
summary: A weak cold front is impacting the Miami Valley, with the best chance of rain after 1pm on Wednesday. Some areas may remain dry, but any rain will bring heavy rain, lightning strikes, and gusty winds. Meanwhile, temperatures are expected to reach the 90s this weekend and continue to rise through the week. The average high in Dayton is expected to be 84 degrees by mid-August.
shortSummary: A weak cold front is causing mixed reactions in the Miami Valley, with potential for heavy rain and strong winds.
argos_summary: A weak cold front is bringing the best chance of rain to the Miami Valley on Wednesday, with scattered storms expected after 1 pm, though severe weather is not anticipated. Schools in Montgomery and Preble Counties are reopening, and while the morning bus stop forecast is dry, storms may affect students heading home. Following a cooler Thursday, high temperatures will surge into the 90s over the weekend, with another cold front expected to bring a cooling trend next week.
